Factorisation

1. Revision of common factors

Introduction to factorisation: fill in the blank

The equation here shows the factorisation of the expression 6x+246x+24. However, there is one value missing from the answer. What is the missing value?

6x+24=?⎯⎯⎯⎯(x+4)6x+24=?_(x+4)
Answer:
expression
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
You must find a number (or variable) which makes the equation true. Try putting a value into the blank and then distributing into the brackets to see if you get 6x+246x+24.
STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about factorisation: we have the equation 6x+24=?⎯⎯⎯⎯(x+4)6x+24=?_(x+4) and we must fill in the missing value to make the equation true.

Factorisation is the inverse (the reverse) of the distributive law. When we factorise, we are "undoing" the distributive law. In other words, factorisation is when you "un-expand" or "undistribute" an expression. The picture below shows the relationship between distributing and factorising. When you multiply into the brackets you are distributing; when you put a number back outside of the brackets, you are factorising.

The equation given is: 6x+24=?⎯⎯⎯⎯(x+4)6x+24=?_(x+4). Imagine distributing the ?? into the brackets: we need a number so that ?×x?×x will be equal to 6x6x. (It also must work out that ?×4?×4 will be 2424.) This means that the missing value must be 66.

Here are some important facts about factorisation:

  • the number of terms in the brackets is equal to the number of terms in the original expression
  • the value outside of the brackets is the HCF (Highest Common Factor) of the terms in 6x+246x+24
  • we can check the answer with the distributive law:
    6(x+4)6x+24⟵Expand thebrackets⟵Cool - this is theoriginal expression6(x+4)⟵bracketsExpand the6x+24⟵original expressionCool - this is the

The correct answer for the missing value is: 66.

[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

To factorise this expression we must take out the highest common factor (HCF) from all the terms.

STEP: Identify the highest common factor (HCF) of all the terms and factor it out
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

To factorise this expression we must take out the highest common factor (HCF) from all the terms. In this case the HCF is 12d12d, so we get:

84dw2−60df3+84dw6f5=12d(7w2−5f3+7w6f5)84dw2−60df3+84dw6f5=12d(7w2−5f3+7w6f5)

Prime expressions

Answer the two questions which follow about the expression 5x2−25x2−2

  1. What is the HCF (highest common factor) of the terms in the expression?

    Answer:
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    The highest common factor (HCF) of two things is the largest number (or biggest expression) that fits into both things. For example, the HCF of 8y28y2 and 12y12y is 4y4y because it fits into both of the expressions.
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We have the expression 5x2−25x2−2 and we need to find the HCF of the two terms in the expression. The HCF of the two terms is the largest expression (biggest number of factors) you can find which fits into both terms without a remainder.

    The terms 5x25x2 and −2−2 do not have any factors in common: they do not share factors of xx, nor do they share any number factors. In a case like this, the largest common factor is 11.

    The HCF for the terms 5x25x2 and −2−2 is 11.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Is the expression prime or not?

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    "Prime" means that something cannot be broken into smaller factors. For example, 77 is a prime number because it cannot be broken into smaller factors. Similarly, an expression is prime if it cannot be broken in to smaller factors.
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The question asks us to decide if the expression 5x2−25x2−2 is prime or not. "Prime" means that something cannot be broken down into smaller factors. For example, 1010 is not prime because it can be broken down to 2×52×5; but 1111 is prime because it cannot be broken into smaller factors: it can only be written as 1×111×11. The same idea also applies to expressions: an expression is prime if it cannot be broken into factors.

    How does the "prime" concept apply to the expression 5x2−25x2−2? From above we know that the HCF is 11: that means we cannot break up the expression more than this:

    5x2−2⟶1×(5x2−2)5x2−2⟶1×(5x2−2)

    Therefore, the expression in this question is prime.

    The correct choice from the list is: It is prime.

    Submit your answer as:

Introduction to factorisation: multiple choice

For the expression 2x2−3x2x2−3x, which choice below is the correctly factorised expression?

A x(2x−3)x(2x−3)
B 2x(x−3)2x(x−3)
C 3x(2x+1)3x(2x+1)
Answer:

The correctly factorised expression is: .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Use the distributive law to expand the expressions in the table. The correct choice must be equal to 2x2−3x2x2−3x when it is expanded.

STEP: Check the answer choices by expanding them
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about factorisation. We have the expression 2x2−3x2x2−3x and we need to select the choice in the table which is the correctly factorised version of that expression.

Factorisation is the inverse (the reverse) of the distributive law. Factorising means "undoing" the distributive law. In other words, factorisation is when you "un-expand" or "undistribute" an expression. The picture below shows the relationship between distributing and factorising. When we multiply into the brackets we are distributing; when we put a number back outside of the brackets, we are factorising.

We can use the relationship above to find the correct answer to this question! Just start by expanding the first choice in the table with the distributive law to see if it is equal to 2x2−3x2x2−3x:

Expand theexpression......to see if youget 2x2−3x→x(2x−3)→2x2−3xExpand theexpression...→x(2x−3)...to see if youget 2x2−3x→2x2−3x

Fantastic! When we multiply out the first expression we find it is equal to 2x2−3x2x2−3x; that means it is the correctly factorised version of the expression.

The correct choice from the table is: A.

Factorisation with trinomials

Factorise the expression given below.

INSTRUCTION: If it cannot be factorised, type "prime" in the answer box.
24a2+36a−3024a2+36a−30
Answer:
polynomial
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
You need to figure out the HCF of all three terms!
STEP: Determine the HCF (Highest Common Factor) of the terms in the expression
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

You have the expression 24a2+36a−3024a2+36a−30 and you must factorise it. Factorisation is the inverse of the distributive law, which means it is when you "un-expand" or "undistribute" an expression.

The first thing you need to do is find the HCF of the expression. However, the expression is a trinomial, so you must find the HCF of all three terms! The terms are 24a224a2, 36a36a and −30−30. The HCF for these three terms is 66.

STEP: Pull out the HCF, and then use the distributive law to check your answer
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Once you know the HCF, you can factorise the expression. Start by putting the HCF in front of a pair of brackets, like this: 24a2+36a−30=6×(more stuff)24a2+36a−30=6×(more stuff). If you take 66 out of each term in the trinomial you will get 6(4a2+6a−5)6(4a2+6a−5).

Remember that you should always check your answer when you factorise. To check the answer, distribute the HCF back into the brackets to make sure that everything agrees with the original expression. Remember, you must distribute the 66 to all three terms in the brackets.

6(4a2+6a−5)24a2+36a−30⟵All right! this is theoriginal expression6(4a2+6a−5)24a2+36a−30⟵original expressionAll right! this is the

The correct answer is: 6(4a2+6a−5)6(4a2+6a−5).

Factorisation: the distributive law backwards

Factorise the following expression by taking the HCF (Highest Common Factor) of the terms outside of brackets:

x2−5xx2−5x

Your answer should look something like this: 3(x + 7).

Answer:
polynomial
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
You need to figure out the HCF of the two terms first; then use the HCF to get the answer.
STEP: Determine the HCF (Highest Common Factor) of the terms in the expression
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We have the expression x2−5xx2−5x and we must factorise it. Factorisation means that we need to "undo" the distributive law - factorisation is the inverse of distributing. In other words, factorisation is when you "un-expand" or "undistribute" an expression.

The first thing we need to do is find the HCF of the two terms in the expression. (Remember that the HCF is the largest number or value which fits into both of the terms.) For the expression x2−5xx2−5x the HCF of the terms is xx.

STEP: Pull out the HCF, and then use the distributive law to check your answer
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Once you know the HCF, you can factorise the expression. As mentioned above, factorisation is when we "undo" the distributive law. The picture below shows the relationship between distributing and factorising. When you multiply into the brackets you are distributing; when you put a number back outside of the brackets, you are factorising.

In this question we are factorising, so start by putting the HCF in front of a pair of brackets, like this: x2−5x=x(more stuff)x2−5x=x(more stuff). Then you must fill in the brackets so that the expressions are equal.

In this case, if you take xx out of the terms in the expression you will get x(x−5)x(x−5). Can you see why factorisation means "undistributing"?

Checking the answer: When we factorise, we should always take the time necessary to check the answer. To check the answer we need to distribute the HCF, xx, back into the brackets to make sure that everything agrees with the original expression.

x(x−5)x2−5x⟵Multiply the HCFback into the brackets⟵Cool - this is theoriginal expressionx(x−5)⟵back into the bracketsMultiply the HCFx2−5x⟵original expressionCool - this is the

The correct answer is: x(x−5)x(x−5).

More complex HCFs

Factorise the following expression.

INSTRUCTION: If it cannot be factorised, type "prime" in the answer box.
8x2−20x8x2−20x
Answer:
polynomial
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
You need to figure out the HCF of the two terms first; then use the HCF to get the answer.
STEP: Determine the HCF (Highest Common Factor) of the terms in the expression
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

You have the expression 8x2−20x8x2−20x and you must factorise it. Factorisation is the inverse of the distributive law, which means it is when you "un-expand" or "undistribute" an expression.

The first thing you need to do is find the HCF of the two terms in the expression. The two terms are 8x28x2 and −20x−20x. The HCF of the terms is 4x4x.

STEP: Pull out the HCF, and then use the distributive law to check your answer
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Once you know the HCF, you can factorise the expression. Start by putting the HCF in front of a pair of brackets, like this: 8x2−20x=4x×(more stuff)8x2−20x=4x×(more stuff). If you take 4x4x out of the terms in the expression you will get 4x(2x−5)4x(2x−5).

Remember that you should always check your answer when you factorise. To check the answer, distribute the HCF back into the brackets to make sure that everything agrees with the original expression.

4x(2x−5)8x2−20x⟵Bingo! this is theoriginal expression4x(2x−5)8x2−20x⟵original expressionBingo! this is the

The correct answer is: 4x(2x−5)4x(2x−5).

Factorisation

Factorise the expression given below if possible. Type "prime" in the answer box if it cannot be factorised.

20x3+12x2y+12x220x3+12x2y+12x2
Answer:
polynomial
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]
You need to figure out the HCF of all three terms in the expression!
STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

You must factorise the expression 20x3+12x2y+12x220x3+12x2y+12x2. Start by figuring out the HCF of the expression. When dealing with a trinomial, the HCF must come from all three of the terms in the expression.

The HCF for these terms is 4x24x2.

STEP: <no title>
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now factorise the HCF out of the expression. If you take 4x24x2 out of each term in the expression you will get 4x2(5x+3y+3)4x2(5x+3y+3).

Finally, check your answer. Do this by distributing the HCF back into the brackets to make sure you get the original expression. Remember, you must distribute the 4x24x2 to each of the terms in the brackets.

4x2(5x+3y+3) 20x3+12x2y+12x24x2(5x+3y+3) 20x3+12x2y+12x2

The correct answer is: 4x2(5x+3y+3)4x2(5x+3y+3).

STEP: Identify the highest common factor (HCF) of both terms and factorise

Prime expressions

Answer the two questions which follow about the expression 4x−204x−20

  1. What is the HCF (highest common factor) of the terms in the expression?

    Answer:
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    The highest common factor (HCF) of two things is the largest number (or biggest expression) that fits into both things. For example, the HCF of 8y28y2 and 12y12y is 4y4y because it fits into both of the expressions.
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We have the expression 4x−204x−20 and we need to find the HCF of the two terms in the expression. The HCF of the two terms is the largest expression (biggest number of factors) you can find which fits into both terms without a remainder.

    The terms in this expression, which are 4x4x and −20−20, have a number in common, but the variable is not common (it appears only in one of the terms).

    The HCF for the terms 4x4x and −20−20 is 44.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Is the expression prime or not?

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    "Prime" means that something cannot be broken into smaller factors. For example, 77 is a prime number because it cannot be broken into smaller factors. Similarly, an expression is prime if it cannot be broken in to smaller factors.
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The question asks us to decide if the expression 4x−204x−20 is prime or not. "Prime" means that something cannot be broken down into smaller factors. For example, 1010 is not prime because it can be broken down to 2×52×5; but 1111 is prime because it cannot be broken into smaller factors: it can only be written as 1×111×11. The same idea also applies to expressions: an expression is prime if it cannot be broken into factors.

    How does the "prime" concept apply to the expression 4x−204x−20? From above we know that the HCF is 44: that means we can break up the expression into the factors 44 and (x−5)(x−5), like this:

    4x−20⟶4×(x−5)4x−20⟶4×(x−5)

    Therefore, the expression in this question is not prime.

    The correct choice from the list is: It is not prime.

For the expression 3x2+4x3x2+4x, which choice below is the correctly factorised expression?

A x(3x2+4)x(3x2+4)
B x(3x+4)x(3x+4)
C 4x(3x+1)4x(3x+1)
Answer:

The correctly factorised expression is: .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Use the distributive law to expand the expressions in the table. The correct choice must be equal to 3x2+4x3x2+4x when it is expanded.

STEP: Check the answer choices by expanding them
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about factorisation. We have the expression 3x2+4x3x2+4x and we need to select the choice in the table which is the correctly factorised version of that expression.

Factorisation is the inverse (the reverse) of the distributive law. Factorising means "undoing" the distributive law. In other words, factorisation is when you "un-expand" or "undistribute" an expression. The picture below shows the relationship between distributing and factorising. When we multiply into the brackets we are distributing; when we put a number back outside of the brackets, we are factorising.

We can use the relationship above to find the correct answer to this question! Just start by expanding the first choice in the table with the distributive law to see if it is equal to 3x2+4x3x2+4x:

Expand theexpression......to see if youget 3x2+4x→x(3x2+4)→3x3+4xExpand theexpression...→x(3x2+4)...to see if youget 3x2+4x→3x3+4x

Shucks: it did not work out correctly. We needed the expression 3x2+4x3x2+4x but instead we got 3x3+4x3x3+4x. Move on to checking the second choice in the table: expand it using the distributive law. Once you find the expression which is equal to 3x2+4x3x2+4x when you expand it, you have the correct answer.

In this question the correct answer is x(3x+4)x(3x+4) because when we distribute the xx into the brackets we get 3x2+4x3x2+4x.

The correct choice from the table is: B.

The terms are −4a2−4a2, −10ab−10ab and −12ac2−12ac2. Remember that when all of the terms are negative, you should include the negative sign in the HCF. The HCF of the terms is −2a−2a.

Factorise the following expression into two binomials:

x2+13x+42x2+13x+42

Your answer should look something like this: (x + 1)(x + 7).

HINT: <no title>

STEP: Set up the binomials based on the x2x2 term
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

We have the expression x2+13x+42x2+13x+42 and we must factorise it.

To factorise an expression means to write the expression as a product. For example, if you factorise the number 1010, you would write 2⋅52⋅5... 22 and 55 are factors of 1010. In the case of a trinomial like x2+13x+42x2+13x+42 factorising usually leads to two binomials: we want two binomials which have a product equal to x2+13x+42x2+13x+42, just like 22 and 55 have a product of 1010.

To work out the binomial factors requires patience, because there is no single calculation which will give us the answer. Rather we must take the time to work out the answer by trial and error (guess & check).

The first step is to set up the answer based on the x2x2 term in the trinomial. It tells us that the binomials must be like this:

(x+⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+_)(x+_)

Imagine starting FOIL with these two brackets: you will get x2x2 from the two xx's, which is the first part of x2+13x+42x2+13x+42.

STEP: Find the numbers which belong in the binomials
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

So far we have this: x2+13x+42=(x+⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)x2+13x+42=(x+_)(x+_). Now we need to figure out which numbers belong in the empty spaces. Whatever numbers we try to put in the binomials, we must check the binomials with FOIL to make sure that everything works out correctly.

We should try numbers which have a product of 4242. This is because of the "Lasts" term in FOIL. For example, let's check what happens if we try the numbers 11 and 4242:

(x+1)(x+42)x2+42x+x+42x2+43x+42⟵Use FOIL toexpand the product⟵Is this thetrinomial we want?(x+1)(x+42)⟵expand the productUse FOIL tox2+42x+x+42x2+43x+42⟵trinomial we want?Is this the

Shucks - we did not get the trinomial we needed because the xx term is not correct. That means that the binomials (x+1)(x+1) and (x+42)(x+42) cannot be the correct factors.

This is where patience is required: we need to try two other numbers which have a product of 4242 and see if those numbers work out to make the trinomial we need. We must continue this process until we find two binomials which agree with the trinomial. The correct pair of binomials is (x+7)(x+6)(x+7)(x+6) because (x+7)(x+6)=x2+13x+42(x+7)(x+6)=x2+13x+42.

STEP: Break down the square of a binomial pattern

You must factorise the expression z2−6z+9z2−6z+9, which means you must write the expression as a product.

As the title indicates, this expression is a special pattern: it is the square of a binomial. When a square of a binomial is expanded, it matches the pattern in the expression z2−6z+9z2−6z+9: the first and last terms are squared quantities, and the middle term is twice as much as the square root of the last term.

Specifically, the constant term is the square of −3−3, and the coefficient of the middle term is two times as much as −3−3:

z2−6z+9=z2−2(3)z+(−3)2z2−6z+9=z2−2(3)z+(−3)2

Therefore, the binomial factors will contain the number −3−3.

STEP: Find the binomials
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

As usual, it is a good idea to check the binomials to make sure that things work out correctly:

Indeed, these binomials give the correct trinomial.

The correct answer is: (z−3)(z−3)(z−3)(z−3). You can also write this as a true square of a binomial: (z−3)2(z−3)2.

You have the expression x2+4x−12x2+4x−12 and you must factorise it. To work out the binomial factors often requires patience: there is no single calculation which will give you the answer. Rather you must take the time to work out the answer by trial and error (guess & check).

For the expression x2+4x−12x2+4x−12, the first and last terms both give big hints about the binomials that you need. The first term suggests that the factors must both have xx in them: (x)(x)(x)(x).

The last term in x2+4x−12x2+4x−12 tells you about the signs in the binomials. Remember that the number −12−12 usually comes from multiplying the numbers in the binomials (when you do FOIL). Therefore, the binomials must contain one negative sign and one positive sign. Therefore the binomials must be:

(x+⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x−⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+_)(x−_)

So at this point we have x2+4x−12=(x+⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x−⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯)x2+4x−12=(x+_)(x−_).

STEP: Find the numbers which belong in the binomials
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now you need to figure out which numbers belong in the empty spaces. Whatever numbers you try to put in the binomials, you must check the binomials with FOIL to make sure that everything works out correctly.

You should try numbers which have a product of −12−12. For example, let's check what happens with the numbers 22 and −6−6:

(x+2)(x−6)x2−6x+2x−12x2−4x−12⟵Use FOIL toexpand the product⟵Is this thetrinomial we want?(x+2)(x−6)⟵expand the productUse FOIL tox2−6x+2x−12x2−4x−12⟵trinomial we want?Is this the

Nope! This is not the trinomial you needed: the xx-term is not correct. (The other two terms are correct, but maths is very strict - you must get the trinomial x2+4x−12x2+4x−12 exactly, not almost the same trinomial.) That means that the binomials (x+2)(x+2) and (x−6)(x−6) cannot be the correct factors.

Now stay patient: you need to try two other numbers which have a product of −12−12 and see if those numbers work out to make the trinomial x2+4x−12x2+4x−12. You must continue this process until you find two binomials which agree with the trinomial.

The correct answer is: (x−2)(x+6)(x−2)(x+6). You can also write the answer as (x+6)(x−2)(x+6)(x−2).

Factorising x2+bx+cx2+bx+c: true or false

The equation below shows a trinomial factorised into two binomial factors. Are the binomial factors correct or not? (Is the equation true or false?)

x2+12x+35=(x+7)(x+7)x2+12x+35=(x+7)(x+7)
Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
Expand the binomials (with FOIL) to see if the you get the trinomial or not. Be careful to pay attention to the signs in the binomial.
STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Factorisation is the inverse of expanding something. When we factorise, we must break something apart into a product. For example, if you factorise the number 1010, you write 2⋅52⋅5. For a trinomial, it is common that the factors are binomials, like what is shown in this question.

To see if the binomials are the correct factors, we must expand the product to find out if they are equal to the trinomial x2+12x+35x2+12x+35 or not. That means using FOIL:

(x+7)(x+7)x2+7x+7x+49x2+14x+49⟵Use FOIL toexpand the product⟵Is this thetrinomial we want?(x+7)(x+7)⟵expand the productUse FOIL tox2+7x+7x+49x2+14x+49⟵trinomial we want?Is this the

We were supposed to get the trinomial x2+12x+35x2+12x+35! However, the constant term and the xx-term are both wrong. Therefore x2+12x+35x2+12x+35 is not equal to (x+7)(x+7)(x+7)(x+7)

Notice that we checked the answer by expanding the binomials with FOIL and comparing the result to the trinomial in the question. Checking the answer with FOIL is a normal part of factorisation: you will do it over and over again when you are solving factorisation problems.

The correct choice is: False.

Factorising x2+bx+cx2+bx+c: filling in the blank

The equation below shows an incomplete factorisation. What is the missing number?

x2+7x+6=(x+?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+1)x2+7x+6=(x+?_)(x+1)
Answer:
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
Use FOIL on the binomials to see if they are equal. Be careful to pay attention to the signs in the binomial.
STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We have the equation x2+7x+6=(x+?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+1)x2+7x+6=(x+?_)(x+1), which shows an unfinished factorisation question. We must complete the factorisation by filling in the missing number.

To factorise an expression means to write the expression as a product. Factorising the trinomial x2+7x+6x2+7x+6 leads to two binomials: (x+?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+1)(x+?_)(x+1). We need to put a number into the blank space so that the binomials have a product equal to x2+7x+6x2+7x+6.

We must think about FOIL when we factorise into binomials: if we expand the binomials using FOIL we must get the trinomial x2+7x+6x2+7x+6 (because the product must be equal to that trinomial).

(x+?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+1)⟶x2+7x+6(x+?_)(x+1)⟶x2+7x+6

Imagine doing FOIL with these two brackets: the "Lasts" term must be equal to 66! What number should go into the blank space for that to work out?

Notice that the constant term in the trinomial is positive. That is why the signs in the binomials are the same (both positive): positive times positive is positive! 6×1=66×1=6 .

The complete factorised expression is (x+6)(x+1)(x+6)(x+1), and the answer is: 66.

STEP: Factorise x2−10x+21x2−10x+21
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Factorisation usually requires patience: it is not something you can do by following a formula. So give yourself time to find the answer if it does not come quickly.

The most useful thing to look at to start factorisation is the constant term; in this case it is equal to +21+21. That means that when you factorise you must find two numbers which have a product of ('product' means multiply) +21+21. In this case it works out like this:

Special Patterns: The square of a binomial

Factorise the following expression into two binomials:

z2−12z+36z2−12z+36
Answer:
polynomial
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
The pattern is the square of a binomial: the answer must contain identical binomials.
STEP: Break down the square of a binomial pattern
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

You must factorise the expression z2−12z+36z2−12z+36, which means you must write the expression as a product.

As the title indicates, this expression is a special pattern: it is the square of a binomial. When a square of a binomial is expanded, it matches the pattern in the expression z2−12z+36z2−12z+36: the first and last terms are squared quantities, and the middle term is twice as much as the square root of the last term.

Specifically, the constant term is the square of −6−6, and the coefficient of the middle term is two times as much as −6−6:

z2−12z+36=z2−2(6)z+(−6)2z2−12z+36=z2−2(6)z+(−6)2

Therefore, the binomial factors will contain the number −6−6.

STEP: Find the binomials
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now you need to build the binomials which correspond to the trinomial. For a square of binomial pattern, this simply means the same binomial twice using the number you found above, −6−6; in this case the binomials must be (z−6)(z−6)(z−6)(z−6).

As usual, it is a good idea to check the binomials to make sure that things work out correctly:

(z−6)(z−6)z2−6z−6z+36z2−12z+36⟵Use FOIL toexpand the product⟵Is this thetrinomial we want?(z−6)(z−6)⟵expand the productUse FOIL toz2−6z−6z+36z2−12z+36⟵trinomial we want?Is this the

Indeed, these binomials give the correct trinomial.

The correct answer is: (z−6)(z−6)(z−6)(z−6). You can also write this as a true square of a binomial: (z−6)2(z−6)2.

Factorising quadratic expressions

Answer the following two questions about the expression f2+13f+42f2+13f+42.

  1. Factorise the expression. If the expression cannot be factorised, type "prime" in the answer box.

    Answer:
    polynomial
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
    STEP: Check to see if the expression is a special pattern
    [−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

    The question gives the expression f2+13f+42f2+13f+42 and you must factorise it.

    The first thing you should do is check to see if the expression is either a difference of two squares or the square of a binomial. A difference of two squares must have two terms made of squared values, with a subtraction between them. For a square of a binomial, the coefficient of the middle term must be twice as much as the square root of the constant term.

    The expression f2+13f+42f2+13f+42 cannot be a difference of two squares because it is a trinomial (a difference of two squares must be a binomial). What about the square of a binomial? The expression does not follow that pattern either because the constant term is not a square number!

    The expression in this question is neither a difference of two squares nor the square of a binomial - it does not have one of the special patterns.

    STEP: Find the binomials using the signs in the expression
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    Since there is no pattern to follow, you should use the signs in the trinomial to get started with the factorisation. In this case, the constant term is positive which means that the signs in the binomials must be the same. Furthermore, since the middle term is positive, the signs in the binomials must both be "++"

The equation below shows a trinomial factorised into two binomial factors. Are the binomial factors correct or not? (Is the equation true or false?)

x2+6x+5=(x+5)(x+2)x2+6x+5=(x+5)(x+2)
Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
Expand the binomials (with FOIL) to see if the you get the trinomial or not. Be careful to pay attention to the signs in the binomial.
STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Factorisation is the inverse of expanding something. When we factorise, we must break something apart into a product. For example, if you factorise the number 1010, you write 2⋅52⋅5. For a trinomial, it is common that the factors are binomials, like what is shown in this question.

To see if the binomials are the correct factors, we must expand the product to find out if they are equal to the trinomial x2+6x+5x2+6x+5 or not. That means using FOIL:

(x+5)(x+2)x2+2x+5x+10x2+7x+10⟵Use FOIL toexpand the product⟵Is this thetrinomial we want?(x+5)(x+2)⟵expand the productUse FOIL tox2+2x+5x+10x2+7x+10⟵trinomial we want?Is this the

We were supposed to get the trinomial x2+6x+5x2+6x+5! However, the constant term and the xx-term are both wrong. Therefore x2+6x+5x2+6x+5 is not equal to (x+5)(x+2)(x+5)(x+2)

Notice that we checked the answer by expanding the binomials with FOIL and comparing the result to the trinomial in the question. Checking the answer with FOIL is a normal part of factorisation: you will do it over and over again when you are solving factorisation problems.

The correct choice is: False.

We have the equation x2−3x−10=(x−?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+2)x2−3x−10=(x−?_)(x+2), which shows an unfinished factorisation question. We must complete the factorisation by filling in the missing number.

To factorise an expression means to write the expression as a product. Factorising the trinomial x2−3x−10x2−3x−10 leads to two binomials: (x−?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+2)(x−?_)(x+2). We need to put a number into the blank space so that the binomials have a product equal to x2−3x−10x2−3x−10.

We must think about FOIL when we factorise into binomials: if we expand the binomials using FOIL we must get the trinomial x2−3x−10x2−3x−10 (because the product must be equal to that trinomial).

(x−?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+2)⟶x2−3x−10(x−?_)(x+2)⟶x2−3x−10

Imagine doing FOIL with these two brackets: the "Lasts" term must be equal to −10−10! What number should go into the blank space for that to work out?

Notice that the constant term in the trinomial is negative. That is why the signs in the binomials are opposites: negative multiplied by positive is negative! −5×2=−10−5×2=−10 .

The complete factorised expression is (x−5)(x+2)(x−5)(x+2), and the answer is: 55.

We have the equation x2+3x−28=(x+7)(x−?⎯⎯⎯⎯)x2+3x−28=(x+7)(x−?_), which shows an unfinished factorisation question. We must complete the factorisation by filling in the missing number.

To factorise an expression means to write the expression as a product. Factorising the trinomial x2+3x−28x2+3x−28 leads to two binomials: (x+7)(x−?⎯⎯⎯⎯)(x+7)(x−?_). We need to put a number into the blank space so that the binomials have a product equal to x2+3x−28x2+3x−28.

We must think about FOIL when we factorise into binomials: if we expand the binomials using FOIL we must get the trinomial x2+3x−28x2+3x−28 (because the product must be equal to that trinomial).

(x+7)(x−?⎯⎯⎯⎯)⟶x2+3x−28(x+7)(x−?_)⟶x2+3x−28

Imagine doing FOIL with these two brackets: the "Lasts" term must be equal to −28−28! What number should go into the blank space for that to work out?

Notice that the constant term in the trinomial is negative. That is why the signs in the binomials are opposites: negative multiplied by positive is negative! 7×−4=−287×−4=−28 .

The complete factorised expression is (x+7)(x−4)(x+7)(x−4), and the answer is: 44.

Submit your answer as:

4. Difference of two squares

Factorising a difference of two squares

Factorise the following expression into two binomials.

25x2−425x2−4
Answer: 25x2−4=25x2−4=
polynomial
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
The expression 25x2−425x2−4 has a special pattern: it is a difference of two squares. You can use this pattern to get to the answer quickly.
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

You need to factorise the expression 25x2−425x2−4. To work out the binomial factors often requires patience: however, there is a pattern in this expression which lets you get straight to the answer!

The expression 25x2−425x2−4 is a difference of two squares. (Both terms are squared values, and the subtraction is a difference.) The difference of two squares pattern is linked directly to binomials which are identical except for the signs in the binomials:

25x2−4=(5x+2)(5x−2)25x2−4=(5x+2)(5x−2)
NOTE: You can check your answer by multiplying out:
(5x+2)(5x−2)=x2−10x+10x−4=25x2−4(5x+2)(5x−2)=x2−10x+10x−4=25x2−4

The correct answer is: (5x+2)(5x−2)(5x+2)(5x−2).

Factorising complex differences of two squares

Factorise the following expression into two binomials, if possible.

INSTRUCTION: If the expression cannot be factorised, type "prime" in the answer box.
49a2+b249a2+b2
Answer:
string
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
Is the expression in the question a difference of two squares?
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

You need to factorise the expression 49a2+b249a2+b2. Notice that all of the values in the expression are squared values (either square numbers or the square of a variable). The squared values make the expression look like a difference of two squares, but it is a sum, not a difference (it has addition, not subtraction).

A sum of two squares cannot be factorised into binomials: there is simply no way to change the expression into the product of two binomials. For example, try this:

(7a+b)(7a+b)49a2+7ab+7ab+b249a2+14ab+b2⟵Try thesebinomials⟵There is an extra term;It does not work!(7a+b)(7a+b)⟵binomialsTry these49a2+7ab+7ab+b249a2+14ab+b2⟵It does not work!There is an extra term;

An expression which cannot be factorised is called "prime." It is the same as a prime number, like 77: it cannot be broken down into smaller numbers. In the same way, the expression 49a2+b249a2+b2 is prime because it cannot be broken down into smaller pieces.

The correct answer is: prime.

Factorising complex differences of two squares

Factorise the following expression into two binomials, if possible.

INSTRUCTION: If the expression cannot be factorised, type "prime" in the answer box.
x2−81y2x2−81y2
Answer:
polynomial
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
What is the pattern in the binomials for a difference of two squares?
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

You need to factorise the expression x2−81y2x2−81y2. Notice that all of the values in the expression are squared values (either square numbers or the square of a variable). Furthermore, the expression shows a difference (subtraction). All those facts together mean that the expression is a difference of two squares.

For the difference of two squares pattern, the binomials are always identical except for the signs in the binomials:

x2−81y2=(x+9y)(x−9y)x2−81y2=(x+9y)(x−9y)

As always, you should check the binomials to make sure you get the exact expression you need.

(x+9y)(x−9y)x2−9xy+9xy−81y2x2−81y2⟵Use FOIL toexpand the product⟵The two middleterms cancel each other(x+9y)(x−9y)⟵expand the productUse FOIL tox2−9xy+9xy−81y2x2−81y2⟵terms cancel each otherThe two middle

The correct answer is: (x+9y)(x−9y)(x+9y)(x−9y). The order of the binomials is not important, so you can also write the answer as (x−9y)(x+9y)(x−9y)(x+9y).
